title: Katsura River
text:
The is a continuation of two other rivers, the <a href="Hozu%20River">Hozu River</a>, a small, speedy river which begins in the <a href="mountain">mountain</a>s near <a href="Kameoka">Kameoka</a> and then slithers through the mountains separating <a href="Kameoka%2C%20Kyoto">Kameoka</a> and <a href="Kyoto">Kyoto</a>; and the <a href="%C5%8Ci%20River">Ōi River</a> (大堰川 "Ōi-gawa"), which emerges from those mountains and expands into a shallow, slow-flowing river until <a href="Togetsukyo%20Bridge">Togetsukyo Bridge</a> in <a href="Arashiyama">Arashiyama</a>. From that point forward, the river is referred to as the Katsura River, and its flow continues for several kilometers through <a href="Kyoto%20Prefecture">Kyoto Prefecture</a> until it joins the <a href="Kamo%20River">Kamo</a> and <a href="Uji%20River">Uji</a> rivers.
The Katsura River area features some of the oldest shrines in Kyoto and Japan, such as <a href="Matsuo%20Shrine">Matsuo Shrine</a>, and, as a counterpoint to the channelled <a href="Kamo%20River">Kamo River</a>, supports acres of <a href="Agriculture">agricultural</a> area on its flood plain. It also is known for its summer supply of "<a href="ayu">ayu</a>" and is a popular place for holding <a href="barbecue">barbecue</a>s.
